TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: azua ti Salakats keman tua qatjuvi sakamaya.
azoa ti Salakac keman toa qatjovi sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: (Chief) Salakats ate only snakes.

S.FORM: izua i Tjulutun itjua tsuqu a nakisalił a kemakan.
izoa i Tjoloton itjoa coqo a nakisalilj a kemakan.
S.TRANSL: He would go off by himself to eat at Tjulutun by the bischoffia tree(?).

S.FORM: saka nu mangtjez a vadis, sipaḍal a pi katsasavan.
saka no mangtjez a vadis, sipadral a pi kacasavan.
S.TRANSL: When the tribute meat was brought, he left it (on the platform) in the courtyard.

S.FORM: qau nu tsuatsuay anga madjapeng izua.
qao no coacoay anga madjapeng izoa.
S.TRANSL: After a long time it rotted away there.

S.FORM: manu izua za Tjulung: "aku su ayain tsa vutjuł?
mano izoa za Tjolong: "ako so ayain ca votjolj?
S.TRANSL: Some people of the Tjulung family said: “Why do you do that to this meat?

S.FORM: paulain.
paolain.
S.TRANSL: It’s a waste.

S.FORM: nia alapaw sa nia kani," aya azuaza Tjulung.
nia alapaw sa nia kani," aya azoaza Tjolong.
S.TRANSL: We’ll take and eat it,” said the Tjulung family.

S.FORM: sisalu ni Salakats.
sisalo ni Salakac.
S.TRANSL: Salakats agreed;

S.FORM: alapen ni Tjulung sa vaik.
alapen ni Tjolong sa vaik.
S.TRANSL: so the Tjulung people took it and went off.

S.FORM: qau tjału zua i tji Taupili, gemugu: "azua inika kanen ni Luvaniaw a vadis, muri a niamen anga a kadjunangan, azua i Małipa Tjuaqatsiłay," aya azua ła Tjulung.
qao tjaljo zoa i tji Taopili, gemogo: "azoa inika kanen ni Lovaniaw a vadis, mori a niamen anga a kadjonangan, azoa i Maljipa Tjoaqaciljay," aya azoa lja Tjolong.
S.TRANSL: When they got to the Taupili house they shouted out: “The tribute meat has not been eaten by the Luvaniaw family. The land at Małipa Tjauqatsiłay will become ours,” said the Tjulung people.

S.FORM: katavakan anga niamadju, aya tjautsikel.
katavakan anga niamadjo, aya tjaocikel.
S.TRANSL: So it was established as theirs, according to the story.

S.FORM: saka sitsuayan a uta tjemałava ła Luvaniaw.
saka sicoayan a ota tjemaljava lja Lovaniaw.
S.TRANSL: At another time long ago the Luvaniaw family got help from others with work.

S.FORM: kemsa ti Salakats tu tsengeł.
kemsa ti Salakac to cengelj.
S.TRANSL: Salakats cooked the midday meal,

S.FORM: pakesaan tua qatjuvi a vulung a kinsa.
pakesaan toa qatjovi a volong a kinsa.
S.TRANSL: and cooked a hundred-pacer snake along with the other food.

S.FORM: sa ka makesa a kinsa, qaqivuin a tjinałava sema tapaw.
sa ka makesa a kinsa, qaqivoin a tjinaljava sema tapaw.
S.TRANSL: When the food was cooked, the helpers were called to the house.

S.FORM: a tjinałava muri keman; pałetekuin a kinsa.
a tjinaljava mori keman; paljetekoin a kinsa.
S.TRANSL: The helpers were going to eat; the food was put out ready,

S.FORM: muri sulamudan nua zuma.
mori solamodan noa zoma.
S.TRANSL: and one of the people was going to take the covering leaves off.

S.FORM: manu "pagału-i a ku kinsa; izua Tjavenikiniki," aya azua ti Salakats.
mano "pagaljo-i a ko kinsa; izoa Tjavenikiniki," aya azoa ti Salakac.
S.TRANSL: But Salakats said: “Be careful of what I’ve cooked. Tjavenikiniki is there,” he said.

S.FORM: "ki anema siayaya Tjavenikiniki?" aya a tjinałava.
"ki anema siayaya Tjavenikiniki?" aya a tjinaljava.
S.TRANSL: “What does he mean by Tjavenikiniki?” said the helpers.

S.FORM: ka sulamudan izua qatjuvi a vulung a sinipakesa namintsekas.
ka solamodan izoa qatjovi a volong a sinipakesa namincekas.
S.TRANSL: When they took the covering leaves off, there was the hundred-pacer snake cooked with the rest and all split open.

S.FORM: qau marekutj a tjinałava.
qao marekotj a tjinaljava.
S.TRANSL: The helpers were afraid.

S.FORM: "kanu, ayain itjen tua pinakesaan tua qatjuvi.
"kano, ayain itjen toa pinakesaan toa qatjovi.
S.TRANSL: “We’re told to eat something cooked together with snake;

S.FORM: tjała semavaqaran," aya a tjinałava; sa kavilad a mapułat, aya a tjautsikel a sitsuayan.
tjalja semavaqaran," aya a tjinaljava; sa kavilad a mapoljat, aya a tjaocikel a sicoayan.
S.TRANSL: it’s really disgusting,” said the helpers. And they all ran away, according to the old story.
